page.title: 19Wild animals in Fulford
page.content: The grey squirrel, which has become very tame, is common in Fulford. It eats fruit, berries, nuts, acorns and seeds.It lives in a domed nest called a dray. The fox started living in the urban surroundings of Fulford after myxomatosis struck British rabbits. It scavenges from dustbins and birdtables but in surrounding farmland it feeds on mice, voles and small songbirds. The fox's home,called an earth,has a long tunnel with a chamber at the end.Rabbits,having now recovered from myxomatosis, are again common in the area. They eat grass, dandelions, groundsel, corn, beet and turnip.Their homes,divided into several different tunneled chambers, are called warrens. The hedgehog thrives in Fulford despite being frequently squashed by cars. They eat beetles, slugs, worms and snails and nest in hedge bottoms.
